questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding an electric circuit is correct?

A. an electric current is only able to flow in an open circuit

B. the magnitude of the current is proportional to the resistance

C. lower diameter wires are able to carry a higher current

D. too high a current may lead to the circuit overheating 1

Correct Answer: D

2. The purpose of an ignition switch is to:

A. connect the battery to the magneto

B. control the primary circuit of the magneto 2

C. connect the contact breaker and condenser in series with the primary coil

D. connect the secondary coil to the distributor

Correct Answer: B

3. Which of the following are all aerodynamic balances?

A. Inset hinge, mass balance and spring tab.

B. Horn balance, balance tab and internal balance. 3

C. Horn balance, inset hinge and mass balance.

D. Internal balance, anti-balance tab and servo tab.

Correct Answer: B

4. Propeller blade angle is:

A. the angle between the relative airflow and the chord line

B. dependent upon RPM and TAS

C. the angle between the blade chord and the plane of rotation 4

D. the difference between effective pitch and geometric pitch

Correct Answer: C

5. The skin of a modern pressurised aircraft:

A. is made up of light alloy steel sheets built on the monocoque principle

B. houses the crew and the payload

C. is a primary load bearing structure carrying much of the loads 5

D. provides aerodynamic lift and prevents corrosion by keeping out adverse weather

Correct Answer: C

6. What does TEM stand for in the context of Human Performance?

A. Threat and Error Management 6

B. Trusted Equipment Mechanic

C. Time Limited Evacuation Medical

D. Tango, Echo, Mike

Correct Answer: A

7. What is the shortest distance between two points on the Earth's globe called:

A. Lambodrome

B. Great circle 7

C. Airway

D. Rhumb Line

Correct Answer: B

8. Leaving ground effect at a given angle of attack the:

A. Induced drag decreases.

B. effective angle of attack decreases. 8

C. lift will remain constant

D. nose tends to pitch down.

Correct Answer: B (Note: The document has checkmarks next to B and
options:
B describes the aerodynamic effect, while C is incorrect.)

9. A turbo-supercharger impeller is driven by:

A. excess torque from the reduction gearbox

B. diversion of exhaust gases by the waste gate using energy that would otherwise be wasted 9

C. a ram air turbine

D. a connection through a gearbox connected to the crankshaft

Correct Answer: B

10. The weight of an aeroplane, which is in level non accelerated flight, is said to act:

A. vertically through the datum point

B. vertically through the centre of pressure

C. vertically through the centre of gravity 10

D. always along the vertical axis of the aeroplane

Correct Answer: C

11. When an aircraft fitted with a classic air-driven artificial horizon decelerates after landing, a wrong indication will be displayed showing a:

A. climbing turn to left

A. over-indicate then under-indicate

B. over-indicate

C. under-indicate 11

D. be unaffected

A. low airspeed aerodynamic stall,

C. high airspeed aerodynamic wing stall.

Correct Answer: B

14. With regards to the Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW):

A. It is lower than the Maximum Take-Off Weight by the weight of a payload.

B. It is the maximum weight that an aircraft can be loaded to without useable fuel. 13

C. It is important as exceeding the MZFW may mean that there is insufficient lift to get the aircraft airborne.

D. Is more relevant to aircraft with fuselage fuel tanks.

A. to reduce control effectiveness

B. to reduce stick forces during manoeuvres

A. 25kHZ

B. 25MHZ

D. 8.33kHZ 16

Correct Answer: D

A. It increases from south to north

Correct Answer: C

🧠 AON Aviation Knowledge Test 2

1. The result of Empty Field Myopia is:

A. astigmatism

B. a build-up of pressure within the eye

C. focusing is limited to between 1 and 2 meters 20

D. a tendency to suffer from cataracts in the long term

Correct Answer: C

2. An aircraft is approaching a DME Beacon at 40000 ft, and slang range is 15 NM. What is the ground distance to the nearest NM? (Note: "slang range" likely means slant range)

A. 12 NM

B. 13 NM 21

C. 16 NM

D. 15 NM

Correct Answer: B (Calculation: $\sqrt{15^2 - (40000/6076)^2} \approx \sqrt{225 - 6.58^2} \approx \sqrt{225 - 43.3} \approx \sqrt{181.7} \approx 13.48$)

3. The result of empty field myopia is: (Note: Duplicate question from Q1)

A. Focusing is limited to between 1 and 2 meters 22

B. A tendency to suffer from cataracts in the long term

C. Astigmatism

D. A build-up of pressure with the eye

Correct Answer: A

4. To achieve the maximum range over the ground with a headwind, a turbojet should fly:

A. At a speed faster than 1,32 VMD 23

B. At a speed where the GS to drag ratio is greatest

C. At a speed where the GS to PREQ ratio is greatest

D. At a speed slower than 1,32 VMD

Correct Answer: A

5. When selecting a fuse for an aircraft electrical circuit, the governing factor is:

A. the energy of the circuit

B. the power requirement of the circuit 24

C. the resistance of the circuit

D. the voltage of the circuit

Correct Answer: B

A. make the instrument more sensitive.

B. make lower values of vertical speed easier to read 25

D. PRM's must be seated adjacent to emergency exits

Correct Answer: B

A. Super-alloys are used because of their excellent corrosion resistance

B. Titanium alloy is used in aircraft construction because of its good wear and high temperature tolerance 27

C. Steel is used in aircraft because it is strong and heavy but has poor corrosion resistance

D. Aluminium alloys are used in aircraft construction because they are light, easily machined and have good wear resistance

Correct Answer: B (Note: D is also largely true, but Titanium's high-temp tolerance is a key reason for its use)

D. The magnitude of the current is proportional to the resistance

Correct Answer: C

A. Support the weight of the aircraft

C. Limits the speed of compression of the strut

B. Sector 1 (parallel) or sector 3 (direct)

D. Sector 1 (parallel) 32

Correct Answer: D (Heading 002 is within 70 degrees of the reciprocal 070, indicating Sector 1 Parallel entry)

B. batteries are not sensitive to damage because of their solid construction and sealed casing

Correct Answer: D

D. The distance from the datum to the CP

C. There is no requirement to notify the commander when PRM's are carried.

A. is permanently connected to the battery 36

B. supplies galley power

C. carries all me non-essential loads

D. is connected to the battery in an emergency

Correct Answer: A

questions.text: A particular instrument departure procedure requires a minimum climb rate of 210 feet per NM to 8,000 feet. If you climb with a ground speed of 140 knots, what is the rate of climb required in feet per minute?

490 Correct Answer: C (Calculation: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = Gradient (ft/NM) * GS (NM/min) => 210 * (140/60) = 210 * 2.33 ≈ 490 ft/min)

Assuming the question is simply asking for the pressure error equivalent from QFE to QNH difference relative to elevation, which isn't standard instrument error calculation. Maybe it means indicated 2500 ft when True Altitude is actually 2500 ft above MSL? QFE set indicates height above airfield. If True Alt is 2500ft, height above airfield is 1500ft. Altimeter reads 2500ft. Error = 2500 - 1500 = +1000ft? Also unlikely. The 30ft answer suggests it's related to the pressure difference. 1 hPa ≈ 30ft. QNH-QFE diff = 10hPa = 300ft. This is the difference between QNH altitude and QFE height at MSL. At 1000ft elevation, indicated 2500ft QFE means height AGL is 2500ft. Altitude AMSL = 2500+1000 = 3500ft. The pressure altitude at 3500ft AMSL with QNH 1013 is 3500ft. How 30ft error arises isn't clear from standard definitions. It might be a poorly phrased question or rely on specific diagram context not fully transferred).

questions.text: Use CAP 696, Section 4, MRJT1, as appropriate. Prior to departure an MRJT is loaded with maximum fuel of 20100 liter at an SG of 0.78. Calculate the maximum allowable traffic load that can be carried given the following data: PLTOM 67200 kg, PLLM 54200 kg, DOM 34930 kg, Taxi fuel 250 kg, Trip fuel 9250 kg, Contingency and holding fuel 850 kg, Alternate fuel 700 kg.
options:
16842 kg Correct Answer: B (Fuel Mass = 20100 L * 0.78 kg/L = 15678 kg. Takeoff Fuel = Fuel Mass - Taxi Fuel = 15678 - 250 = 15428 kg. Max TOM based on fuel = ZFW + TOF. Max ZFW based on PLTOM = PLTOM - TOF = 67200 - 15428 = 51772 kg. Max ZFW based on PLLM = PLLM - TOF + Trip + Contingency + Holding = 54200 - 15428 + 9250 + 850 = 48872 kg. Limiting ZFW = 48872 kg. Max Traffic Load = Limiting ZFW - DOM = 48872 - 34930 = 13942 kg. Self-correction: Let's re-read the fuel amounts. Trip=9250, Cont+Hold=850, Alt=700. Total Required Fuel (excl Taxi) = 9250+850+700 = 10800 kg. Max Fuel loaded = 15678 kg. ZFW limited by PLTOM: Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - 15428 = 16842 kg. ZFW limited by PLLM: Max Landing Mass = PLLM = 54200 kg. Landing Mass = TOM - Trip Fuel. So Max TOM based on PLLM = PLLM + Trip Fuel = 54200 + 9250 = 63450 kg. Max Traffic Load = Max TOM based on PLLM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 63450 - 34930 - 15428 = 13092 kg. There's also likely a Max Structural ZFW limit not given. Assuming PLTOM is the most limiting factor for TOM (67200kg). Max Traffic Load = PLTOM - DOM - Takeoff Fuel = 67200 - 34930 - (15678 - 250) = 16842 kg. Assuming PLLM is limiting: Max TOM = 63450kg. Max Traffic Load = 63450 - 34930 - (15678-250) = 13092 kg. The checkmark is B (12442 kg). This doesn't match either structural limit calculation. There might be a Max Structural ZFW missing, which is often the most limiting factor for traffic load. If MSZFW = 47372 kg, then Max Traffic Load = 47372 - 34930 = 12442 kg. This matches B.)

questions.text: An aircraft is flying at 1.3VS1g in order to provide an adequate margin above the low speed buffet and transonic speeds. If the 1.3VS1g speed is 180 kt CAS and the mass increases from 285000 kg to 320000 kg, what is the new 1g stalling speed?
options: 146.7 kt, drag will increase and nautical mile per kg fuel burn will decrease
191 kt, drag will increase and range NM/kg will increase

A blockage occurs in the ram air source and the drain-hole. The ASI in a nonpressurized aircraft will: A. read a little low B. read a little high C. act like an altimeter D. freeze at zero Correct Answer: C 6. A rate integrating gyroscope is used in: i. inertial attitude system ii. automatic flight control systems iii. inertial navigation systems iv. rate of turn indicators A. i ii B. i iii C. i iii iv D. i ii iii Correct Answer: B 7. When accelerating on a northerly heading what does the direct reading magnetic compass indicate? A. No change B. North C. A turn to the west D. A turn to the east Correct Answer: B (Acceleration error on North/South headings causes no turn indication) Self-correction: The source checkmark is B, but acceleration error (ANDS - Accelerate North, Decelerate South) applies to East/West headings. On a Northerly heading, acceleration causes no turning error. Rechecking compass errors confirms this. The source checkmark might be incorrect. 8. In an IRS: A. the accelerometers are strapped down but the platform is gyro-stabilized B. the platform is strapped down but the accelerometers are gyro-stabilized C. accelerometers and gyros are both gyro-stabilized D. accelerometers and gyros are both strapped down Correct Answer: D 9. To convert true track to magnetic track you need: A. a deviation map B. a map with isoclinal lines C. a map with isobars D. a deviation card Correct Answer: B (Isoclinal lines show dip, Isogonal lines show variation. Variation is needed. Assuming isoclinal is a typo for isogonal.) 10. The rate of turn indicator is a very useful gyroscopic instrument. When used in conjunction with the attitude indicator it provides: A. angle of bank B. rate of turn about the yaw axis C. rate of climb D. rate of turn athwartships Correct Answer: B 11. The outputs of a flux valve are initially sent to: A. an amplifier B. an error detector C. a compass card D. a feedback loop Correct Answer: B 12. An inertial reference system is aligned when turned on so as to: A. calculate the computed trihedron with reference to the earth B. establish true and magnetic north C. establish position relative to true and magnetic north D. establish magnetic north Correct Answer: A 13. Why is there a vibration device in a pressure altimeter? i. To prevent hysteresis ii. To prevent lag in a mechanical system iii. To keep pilots happy during long flights iv. To prevent icing A. i B. i ii C. i iv D. i ii iii iv Correct Answer: B (Primarily overcomes friction/stiction, which relates to lag and hysteresis). 14. An aircraft flies into a colder airmass. This will cause the altimeter to: A. over-read B. under-read C. read the correct altitude D. the indication will depend on the hemisphere of operation Correct Answer: A ("High to Low, look out below" applies to pressure, but "Cold = Low" applies to temperature effect on true altitude vs indicated altitude. Colder air is denser, altimeter reads higher than true altitude, hence over-reads.) 15. In a solid state gyroscope the purpose of the dither motor is to: A. enhance the acceleration of the gyro at all rotational rates B. overcome laser lock C. compensate for transport wander D. stabilize the laser frequencies Correct Answer: B 16. With the aircraft weight constant but variations in airfield altitude, take-off will always be at a constant: A. equivalent airspeed B. calibrated airspeed C. ground speed D. true airspeed Correct Answer: B (Takeoff speeds are typically defined in IAS/CAS). 17. An IRS differs from an INS in that it: A. has a longer spin-up (is not affected by vertical accelerations due to gravity) B. has a shorter spin-up time and suffers from laser lock. C. does not need to correct for coriolis and central acceleration) D. does not suffer Schuler oscillations Correct Answer: B (IRS uses strapdown tech, faster alignment, Ring Laser Gyros can suffer laser lock, which dither motors prevent). 18. The rigidity (gyroscopic inertia) of a gyro rotor is improved by: A. increasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor B. increasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor C. decreasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass on the periphery of the rotor D. decreasing the angular momentum and concentrating the mass at the hub of the rotor Correct Answer: A 19. The errors associated with the directional indicator are: i. earth rate ii. transport wander iii. banking when pitched up iv. annual movement of the poles v. mechanical problems A. i ii iii B. i ii iv v C. i ii iii iv v D. i ii iii v Correct Answer: D 20. Which of the following correctly describes the gyroscope of a rate of turn indicator? i. 1 degree of freedom ii. 2 degrees of freedom iii. Its frame is held by two springs iv. Its spin axis is parallel to the pitch axis v. The spin axis is parallel to the yaw axis vi. The spin axis is horizontal A. i ii B. i iv v C. i iii iv D. i iii vi Correct Answer: C (1 DoF, spring restrained, spin axis parallel to lateral/pitch axis). ⚙️ Instrumentation Test 3 1. An aircraft in the northern hemisphere lands and decelerates on a westerly heading. The compass will indicate: A. a turn north 1B. no turn will be indicated 2C. an oscillation 3D. a turn south 4Correct Answer: D 5 2. The angle formed between the directive force and the total magnetic force is called: A. variation 6B. deviation 7C. dip 8D. isoclinal 9Correct Answer: C 10 3. The ability of a gyroscope to indicate aircraft heading is based on it having: A. one degree of freedom in the vertical axis 11B. two degrees of freedom in the vertical axis 12C. two degrees of freedom in the horizontal 13D. one degree of freedom in the horizontal 14Correct Answer: A 15 4. If the TAS at 40000 ft is 450 kt the Mach No. is: A. 0.

questions.text: The local speed of sound at mean sea level at ISA -10ï¿½C is:
The output of a double integration N/S is:
options: velocity 16B. departure 17C. distance 18D. longitude 19Correct Answer: C 20 (Integrating acceleration gives velocity, integrating velocity gives distance). 7. If a constant CAS is maintained under normal conditions in the climb what happens to the Mach No.? A. It will decrease 21B. It will remain constant 22C. It will decrease in an isothermal layer 23D. It will increase 24Correct Answer: D 25 (Climbing at constant CAS, TAS increases. LSS decreases with altitude (in troposphere). Mach No = TAS/LSS, so Mach increases). 8. The magnetic heading reference unit has a precession rate of: A. 1ï¿½/min
